name: Runestone Keeper
description: Runestone Keeper is a roguelike dungeon crawler that blends classic RPG elements and turn based strategy. Heroes, monsters, equipment, events, magic and skills, traps and devices, shrines and altars, Goddesses and merchants. Choose your weapon and begin an epic adventure!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/Windows 7/Windows 8/Windows 10 Processor: Pentium 4 3.0GHz or higher Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: ATI Radeon 2400 / NVIDIA 8600M / Intel HD Graphics 3000 or higher DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 512 MB available space Sound Card: DirectX 9.0c compatible sound card

reviews.review_text: Gorgeous & very addictive game with nice pixel graphics & hefty sound-effects.  Objective: Delve into the dungeon as deeply as possible.  You have to act carefully and manage your recources to reach the deeper levels of the dungeon. There you find new gods to worship, better equipment, 'runes' and the opportunity to unlock new adventurers to travel even further during your next attempt. When you die (and you will die frequently, thereby loosing your precious equipment) you restart from level 1 again, possibly with a new character, worshipping a new god granting important boni. Fortunately you retain the skills you paid for during the whole game and the gold you earned with the previous character (I'm unsure about the tatoo's...). During your travel in the random levels you will find traps, treasure chests, special single-use equipment, shops with weapons and armor, teachers, rune-smiths, shrines, tatoo-artists and as a matter of course: many, many monsters and elite-monsters! All monsters are attached to their segment but have very nasty special abilities. Hence it's important to watch out for their interplay with the dungeon and the other opponents and to fight them in the correct order, killing ranged attackers first. Sometimes it's better to skip a fight - if possible - but in doing so, you loose the opportunity for important loot, that you might need later on. Some monsters even carry the key you need to get to the next level...  I especially like the feature that some dungeon levels have 'sub-levels' that can be unlocked for more monsters and loot. Remarkable are the non-combat random encounter's during the game with different outcomes, depending on your reactions/answers - often conected with your intelligence-score.  Great game, absolutely worth every eurocent! = 9/10
What is Runestone Keeper?

Truly a fun roguelike. And I consider it unique and certainly worth it's money.  However the gameplay is stiffling. It's not a true roguelike, as some elements carry over between runs, namely runes, gold and shop unlockables. Main problem are the runes, any rune collected and not used carries over to the next game, they are very powerful and rare. The key to success is to use the runes wisely. Additionally, many gamemodes (look up runewords) cost runes to play (most notably the endless runeword)  after your death, you can spend your gold in the shop to get passive upgrades to make the game slightly easier.  So what you end up doing is grinding. Grinding gold and runes in order to pay your expenses in a serious run, where you may want to play with a certain runeword, have prepared runes for certain gods you intend to worship and get tatoos from, and stock gold for certain items you hope to find in shops.  So when you do have a good run, you might not want to go all in in and spend your runes on the much neded tatoos in case you mess up and loose your entire investment.  What I want to recommend is a true roguelike, where every run is a chance to play it big, where you can play all in whitout having to grind for it on countless runs in advance. Things this game regrettably isn't.

So I got this from a friend, and I have to say, this is a great dungeon crawler, it's a mix of desktop dungeons with roguelike elements where you choose your hero and try to clear a randomized dungeon. I had no expectations and was pleasantly surprised, a small title that's keeping me entertained for hours, it is strangely addicting where every time you die, you get gold and unlock a little more of the game, making yourself slightly more powerful. A bit random and unfair sometimes, but otherwise great.
it's a lot like if Desktop Dungeons relied more on RNG than strategy.
This game is fun. When I first fired it up and played a few times I didnt think much of it. After grinding a little bit I started to get a bit more powerful. Now I think I might be addicted.

It's a Minesweeper-esque styled, Dungeon crawler, Turn-based RPG Roguelike, and it works really, really well! You decend from level to level, starting with nothing more than basic equipment, clearing floors of various monsters, earning experience and items, which all, of course, get lost on death. You do keep the gold you earn, though, which is used to upgrade skills or buy items offered in your town. There are also shops scattered throught the dungeon floors, where you can buy, and sell loot you've acquired (hint: best to sell what you have, when you can, if you know you're going to die soon!). The lore is much deeper than I expected, as well as the strategy it takes to make it to the deeper levels. There is plenty to unlock, and keep you coming back.   While it's not at all similar to FTL, gameplay-wise (besides both being roguelikes), it very much reminds me of that game. It's in that same wheelhouse. The production level has a high amount of polish to it, in everything from the art/graphics to the sounds and music. I'd say that if you like games like FTL, or Risk of Rain, but are looking for something a little different, you should definitely check out Runestone Keeper.
An addictive indie game,you will wonna try it again and again..smart idea with beautiful indie graphics. Interface needs some tweaks in case of buttons to be more easy to use. 7.9/10

This game is really my cup my tea that i have never met the challenge. Getting equipments and gradually becimming a big boss usually costs me nearly 2hours but only date back to the newbie for your once failure which is really challenging.11hours is just beginnimg,To become a skiller,much more time needed.Well,Gods bless me that i can surivive to the final battle.
For this games,there re something what i can be addicted to for long long time.

Buy it on super sale, otherwise, NO.   Its fun for about...4 hours, then it becomes a no-fun-point-and-click-grind-athon.   I can't unlock any more characters... can't get past the...7th floor at best, even with upgrades (that seem to help very little). The rouge-like elements suck, quite honestly. The carry over of gold on most plays is in the double digits. Takes forever to buy upgrades that way. Super frustrating. I think I'm done. I feel like I MUST be doing something wrong for it to be this messed up but I'm completely out of patience to reseach what's wrong.   TL:dr:   I got it in a bundle, otherwise, I'd be REAL mad. As is, I'm only a little mad. I think I'm mostly mad because I loved it intensely at first, but then I felt like I hit a solid wall at about the 4 hour mark. Now, no progress, no fun, I'm done.

A game that could be brilliant if only a couple of things were re-designed.   There's no winning strategy - on one hand you have to click each tile to have a chance of getting the items/upgrades that'll be needed to progress, but on the other hand you are severely punished for doing so by unavoidable spike traps, poison traps, etc - which would be fine if there were a stretegic counter but there is not! (other than the ocasional trap detection item you may stumble across... but only by means of clicking tiles and risking traps!)  Look, rng is fine but not when it makes the purpose of the game (clicking tiles, fighting monsters, finding loot) result in random punishments that are not avoidable.  90% of my deaths are ultimately due to traps, so there's definitely a problem here.  Redesign the traps - add an inbuilt trap detection so a player only uncovers the trap when she really *has* to progress beyond a tile (thus strategic decision; hp loss for sake of exploration) or honestly just get rid of them - the game would still be extremely difficult due to the strength and abilities of the monsters you encounter.  It's a vote down until the death by trap syndrome goes away, as the mechanic literally kills the game.
Liked a lot this roguelike + Gameplay + Audio  - More puzzle than roguelike

How can I play a game when the devs don't even know how to speak English properly? Add a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG on top of that, and you have yourself a terrible, terrible game. Thank God I got this in a Humble Bundle I payed $5 for, I can't imagine throwing away $10 for this utter garbage.
A good, simple, fun and engaging game. Simple to play, and fun to explore!  SCORE: 75/100

Really ? After Dungelot i thought this is....more. But, i dont think its better. Mechanics are good, but: The graphics are far from crisp and clean. Dont get me wrong, i love to play Stonesoap, or a tile based Nethack. But the 1920x1080 resolution is hurting my eyes. To justify that graphics are nothing, i love to play risk of rain, or nuclear throne. But the 'ART' is there. And not in this game. Sorry. 6outof10.
its fun but nothing amazing hehe

This has become my go-to roguelike (well, this and HyperRogue), but it is very different from others in that you uncover tiles instead of actually moving a character; so it has more a feel of a puzzle than an adventure, but this also makes it simpler to play than most. This also means that ranged combat is non-directional - the monster will just 'fire' at your character sheet...
Went from recommended to not. Cool point and click dungeon explorer, but it relies more on luck than skill most of the time. Incredibly hard, too

Honestly speaking this game is not a perfect game for me. And based on my experience on such kind of games there are many bugs unfixed in this game, but still i would like to recommend this game to other players. It has been a long time that Chinese game companies havent give a hit product and this one definitely worth to be called as a hit. Also while considering that this game is actually made by a small game studio, this game seems to be extremely precious.
Very interesting Very challenging Customs clearance of achievement is very strong Strongly recommended!!!!!!!!!!!
minesweeper+rpg=addiction

The game's fun, but gets a little bit annoying. You might suddenly end up dead from a really good run, which is nice because you NEED to die a couple of times in order to progress further down in the dungeons. It's mindnumblingly grindy. You do get better at the game, but even then you only learn to minimize risk, to supress the 100%ter inside of you and go for small, reasonable plays.  Sometimes you step down into a dungeon grid and the game simply gives you a 0% chance to survive. It might be that there are a dozen poison traps waiting for you and you know that in three more actions you're dead, or it might be that the monster abilities work together to make them impossible to kill without some specific item, that you couldn't have known you needed and had a small chance of picking up in the first place.  ... why do I recommend this game again?

You know this is an addictive game when you look at the time and see you've been mouse clicking tiles for the last 2 hours. I recommend this game to anyone who comes home from work, see that the family are watching some pants show on TV and want something to chill out to while scoffing your Tea.  I've hit thumbs up for the hours I've already spent and the knowledge that I'll play the game for a few hours more. But, there comes a point when you're spending more time trying to get a good run than being on a good run and think to yourself... should I be playing something else instead?
Click Dungeon, but it's actually kinda fun.
